How Motion-Control Influences a VR-Supported Technology for Mental Rotation Learning: From the Perspectives of Playfulness, Gender Difference and Technology Acceptance Model

Po-Han Lin National Taipei University of Education, International Master's Program of Learning and Instruction, Taipei, Taiwan
View further author information
 & Shih-Ching Yeh School of Information Science and Technology, Fudan University, Shanghai, ChinaCorrespondenceshihching.yeh@gmail.com

              Articles

              How Motion-Control Influences a VR-Supported Technology for Mental Rotation Learning: From the Perspectives of Playfulness, Gender Difference and Technology Acceptance Model

              • Full Article
              • Figures & data
              • References
              • Citations
              • Metrics
              • Reprints & Permissions
              • PDF

              ABSTRACT

              ABSTRACT

              Spatial training has been shown to help student’s university retention rates and performance. The goal of this study is: (1) to explore users’ acceptance of a virtual-reality-supported technology for mental-rotation learning and (2) to examine the effects of interactivity and gender on acceptance. Little is known about whether college students nowadays perceive motion-control and virtual-reality technology as novel and interesting and how gender affects their acceptance of technology. Two learning programs were developed using motion-control and virtual-reality technologies. Learners could actively manipulate the learning object or they could only passively learn. User’s acceptance of the training program (rather than mental-rotation performance) was compared. Results showed higher levels of perceived playfulness, ease of use, usefulness, and use-intention scores were found in motion-control training, suggesting interactivity is still attractive. However, gender difference was also found. While perceived ease of use was a major contributor to training use-intention for both genders, influence of perceived playfulness on use-intention was found only in women.

              1. Introduction

              The importance of spatial training in academics has recently been recognized because of its potential to influence college students’ university retention rates and STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) performance (Carbonell-Carrera, Avarvarei, Chelariu, Draghia, & Avarvarei, 2017; Shea, Lubinski, & Benbow, 2001; Uttal, Miller, & Newcombe, 2013; Wai, Lubinski, & Benbow, 2009). For example, in a 20-year longitudinal study, Sorby (2009) found female college students (also some male students) who participated in a spatial training course earned significantly higher grades in calculus and physics. Retention rates (for university education) were also higher for those who enrolled in the training course (Sorby, 2009). Thus, it is apparent that spatial training could have enormous impact on science and education. It could have a significant long-term effect on students’ school readiness. It could also be a potential route to increase the number of students pursuing STEM-related majors or occupations.

              In this study, we are interested in introducing and evaluating two new virtual reality (VR) spatial learning systems, designed to enhance students’ understanding of a mental rotation (MR) process by visualizing the object’s rotational process. Two computer-assisted MR training programs were developed using VR (3-dimensional stereovision) and motion-control technologies: (1) interactive motion-control training and (2) observation-only training. The two training groups differed in the availability of motion-control technology. In the interactive motion-control training group, motion-control technology allowed students to freely rotate the learning object. It enabled students to conduct operations based on instinct, which is assumed to improve the learning experience by elevating their sense of participation, playfulness, and motivation. In contrast, students in the observation-only training group could learn only through passive observation. In short, this study examines the possibility of utilizing motion-control technology for spatial training purposes. Two training groups were evaluated based on students’ acceptance and elicited perceptions.

              Understanding the user’s acceptance of computer-assisted learning/training is important because technological acceptance has been shown to be related to the actual use of new technology (Davis, 1989; Marangunić & Granić, 2014). Higher acceptance rates for a product increase the chance that the product will be used continuously in the future. Continued training is extremely important in the spatial training domain. As Miller and Halpern (2013) pointed out, exposure to enriching trainings may need to be sustained over several semesters or even years to close the current gender gap in spatial ability and to induce a necessary long-term STEM improvement. Therefore, the ultimate success or failure of a computer application depends on the user’s attitude toward continual use of a training program (Igbaria, Parasuraman, & Pavri, 1990; Loyd & Gressard, 1984). In other words, for training to be considered successful, it needs to be accepted by the users and to be incorporated into their routine in the future. While many computer-assisted spatial training studies have demonstrated the learning effects of trainings (e.g., Parsons et al., 2004; Rizzo et al., 1998; Wiedenbauer & Jansen-Osmann, 2008; Yeh et al., 2013), more studies are needed to examine factors influencing user’s acceptance rates and feelings/perceptions elicited by a computer-assisted training program (e.g., Carbonell-Carrera, Jaeger, & Shipley, 2018; Carbonell-Carrera & Saorín, 2017). By exploring the factors influencing user’s acceptance, we hope to reveal key elements that may be related to users’ willingness for future continuous use of a computer-assisted spatial learning program.

              The Technology Acceptance Model (TAM; Davis, 1989) was employed as a theoretical framework to explore potential factors affecting student acceptance of a training program. The original model (Davis, 1989) and its subsequent extended models included both extrinsic and intrinsic motivators to explain the intention of using a technology. The two extrinsic motivators, (1) perceived usefulness and (2) ease of use, have shown to be the key determinants in people’s intention to use a technology (King & He, 2006; Lee, Cheung, & Chen, 2005; Taherdoost, 2018; Zainab, Bhatti, & Alshagawi, 2017). According to TAM, the characteristics of a technology are regarded as extrinsic motivators. In this study, motion-control technology provided interactivity and this interactivity is assumed to be the extrinsic motivator. Interactivity, which allowed intuitive motion-control of the learning object and instant visual feedback, was hypothesized to increase user’s feelings of ease of use and perceived usefulness of the interactive training, and thus to increase acceptance of using the interactive training method (as compared to the observation-only training). However, this hypothesis must be evaluated across different generations because of the inevitable changes in their familiarity with the technologies. Students at the university level are already considered digital natives who are very familiar with new technology. They may perceive and use technology differently than previous generations (Junco & Mastrodicasa, 2007). Specifically, they may not perceive the interactivity of motion-control technology as novel and interesting. Student’s perceived usefulness and ease of use of using motion-control technology must be evaluated to determine whether interactivity elicits higher acceptance and is associated with a higher chance of future sustained use of the training method. The results of this study also helped to increase the generalizability and applicability of TAM in the spatial training domain (Marangunić & Granić, 2014).

              In addition to the two aforementioned extrinsic motivators (ease of use and perceived usefulness), researchers have started to examine how intrinsic motivators and contextual factors influence people’s technological acceptance. More research have started to examine the relationship among intrinsic motivators, contextual factors, and the two extrinsic motivators (Svendsen, Johnsen, Almas-Sorensen, & Vitterso, 2013). In this study, the intrinsic motivator referred to feelings elicited by the experience of using a technology and the contextual factor referred to the users’ gender. Specifically, we are interested in examining whether the feeling of computer playfulness influences student’s acceptance of the training programs. Computer playfulness is defined as the tendency of an individual to spontaneously, inventively, and imaginatively interact with computers (Webster & Martocchio, 1992). Although playfulness is widely accepted as one of the newly introduced keys in the TAM, its proposed relationship with regard to both perceived usefulness and ease of use remains controversial (Moon & Kim, 2001; Venkatsh, 2000; Venkatesh & Davis, 2000). Similarly, as will be discussed in the literature review section, results on how gender plays a role in users’ technological acceptance of a product remain under-explored and contradictory (Padilla-Meléndez, Aguila-Obra, & Garrido-Moreno, 2013). Therefore, the question of whether playfulness and gender factors are key determinants of acceptance of the VR motion-control training, is examined in this study.

              In sum, the purpose of this study is twofold. Firstly, we are interested in testing an extended TAM to explain influential factors that affect users’ intention of using our MR trainings. Specifically, perceived playfulness was added to the TAM as an intrinsic motivator to acceptance of the VR motion-control technology. Secondly, the effect of gender on the TAM of the VR motion-control training program was also examined. Results of this study contribute to the literature by examining whether interactive hands-on-experience (interactive VR motion-control technology) elicited a higher level of perceived playfulness and acceptance as compared to the traditional method of passive observation. It also helps to extend the generalizability and applicability of TAM to the spatial training domain.

              2. Literature review

              2.1. Technology acceptance model (TAM) and its extension

              The TAM was proposed by Davis (1989) based on the theory of reasoned action (TRA; Fishbein & Ajzen, 1975). It is the most frequently cited model for evaluating users’ acceptance rates of technological products (Marangunić & Granić, 2014). According to the TAM, the external variables (i.e., characteristics of a technological system) influence both perceived ease of use and usefulness (of the system). The two factors exert their influences on attitude toward using the system, and subsequently affect the actual use (of the system. See Figure 1). Perceived ease of use is defined as the degree to which the user believes that the use of a particular technology will be intuitive and free of effort, whereas perceived usefulness is defined as the degree to which the user believes the technology will be beneficial to enhance his/her job performance (Marangunić & Granić, 2014). Ease of use is viewed as the primary factor and is related to perceived usefulness. It exerts both a direct and an indirect (through usefulness) influence on attitude toward using a technological product (Davis, 1989).

              How Motion-Control Influences a VR-Supported Technology for Mental Rotation Learning: From the Perspectives of Playfulness, Gender Difference and Technology Acceptance Model

              All authors
              Po-Han Lin & Shih-Ching Yeh
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2019.1571784
              Published online:
              12 February 2019

              Figure 1. Pictorial illustration of the proposed model. The outer box framed the TAM proposed by Venkatesh and Davis (1996, p. 453). The letter H along with different numbers stand for various hypotheses tested in the study.

              Display full size

              Figure 1. Pictorial illustration of the proposed model. The outer box framed the TAM proposed by Venkatesh and Davis (1996, p. 453). The letter H along with different numbers stand for various hypotheses tested in the study.

              Subsequent models based on the original TAM models were development. These extended TAM models aimed to explore antecedent factors (intrinsic or extrinsic) that are assumed to be related to influence user’s perceived ease of using a product. Subsequent models also focused on examining other moderating factors to improve the predictability of the TAM. For example, Venkatesh (2000) proposed that users’ general belief on their ability to use a computer (or past experience) such as self-efficacy or computer anxiety may have direct effect on the ease of use. Similarly, Venkatesh and Bala (2008) suggested that users’ experiences have moderating effects on the key determinants in the TAM. In short, previous literature has shown that the theoretical framework that TAM provides can act as an appropriate and valid model for predicting students’ acceptance of technological learning platforms (King & He, 2006; Padilla-Meléndez et al., 2013). Therefore, we have chosen to use TAM as an analytical model to examine students’ user satisfaction for our interactive VR motion-control MT training program.

              In the context of TAM, we examine how our trainings affect students’ extrinsic and intrinsic motivators. Extrinsic motivation is defined as the performance of an activity for the purpose of achieving valued outcomes that are distinctive from the feelings that derived from the activity itself (Padilla-Meléndez et al., 2013). In the TAM, perceived usefulness and ease of use are considered as extrinsic motivators (Lee et al., 2005). In contrast, intrinsic motivation is defined as the performance of an activity for no apparent reasons other than the process of doing the activity (Padilla-Meléndez et al., 2013). Playfulness, enjoyment, and flow are some of the intrinsic motivators proposed in the TAM (Venkatesh, 2000).

              In this study, the intuitive motion-control technology is assumed to increase the ease of using the program. As Rizzo (2002) suggested, highly immersive interfaces could facilitate a single ego-center and reduce cognitive overhead; thereby enhancing information processing and learning. Enabling experimentation and comparison with step-by-step control of an object allows easier usage and subsequently lowers cognitive load (e.g., Hessler & Henderson, 2013; Rizzo, 2002; Venkatesh, 2000). Giving control over the training activity through availability of an external motion-controller aid, could potentially increase the feeling of ease of use and enhance the perceived usefulness of the program. Thus, we hypothesize that: H1:

              Interactive VR motion-control technology will increase learners’ (H1a) ease of use, (H1b) perceived usefulness and (H1c) intention to use the program (as compared to passive observation)

              2.2. Role of perceived playfulness in the TAM

              In addition to extrinsic motivators, how an often-overlooked intrinsic motivator – emotion, plays a role in users’ acceptance has drawn more research attention (Lee et al., 2005). As mentioned above, with subsequent TAM development, individual variables and environmental variables are included to understand more clearly of how users’ attitudes related to their willingness to use a technology. Perceived playfulness or enjoyment was among the newly introduced key (Venkatesh, 2000).

              The concept of playfulness is a complex variable which is often related to an individual’s psychological simulation, pleasure, and interests (Csikszentmihalyi, 1990). Three different but related terms have been studied with the TAM model. They are perceived enjoyment, flow, and perceived playfulness. Perceived joyfulness is defined as how enjoyable the use experience of a specific system is without consideration of external performance consequences (e.g., improve job performance, better pay, etc; Venkatesh, 2000). As Csikzentmihalyi (1990, p. 4) defined, “flow is the state in which people are so involved in an activity that nothing else seems to matter; the experience itself is so enjoyable that people will do it even at great cost, for the sheer sake of doing it.” Perceived playfulness is defined as the psychological state of playfulness or flow, which resulted from enjoyment or pleasurable feelings that an individual experienced when doing the activity itself rather than from extrinsic rewards (Moon & Kim, 2001). The term joyful is related to the term playful, however, the feelings associated with the two terms are different. Davis, Bagozzi, and Warshaw (1992) associated enjoyment with intrinsic motivation, and have shown that enjoyment has a significant impact on acceptance of technology.

              While many studies have demonstrated that perceived playfulness is an important and relevant intrinsic motivator, its relationship to other factors in the TAM model remains controversial and debated. In some studies, perceived playfulness is regarded as an antecedent factor to either perceived ease of use, perceived usefulness or both (e.g., Hong, Hwang, Hsu, Wong, & Chen, 2011; Padilla-Meléndez et al., 2013; Venkatesh, 2000; Venkatesh & Bala, 2008; Yi & Hwang, 2003). In other studies, playfulness is proposed as a consequence of perceived ease of use, perceived usefulness, or both (e.g., Chang, Hung, Chen, Wu, 2015; Lee et al., 2005; Moon & Kim, 2001; Terzis & Economides, 2011b). Therefore, the relationship of how perceived playfulness is related to perceived ease of use and usefulness remains to be determined. In addition, the questions of whether playfulness only exerts an indirect influence (mediation) on system use-intention through the perception of ease of use or usefulness or does it impose a direct effect on use intention, are examined in this study.

              One of the goals of the study is to test the direct and indirect effect of perceived playfulness on the intention to use a computer-assisted training program. Playfulness is hypothesized to be an antecedent to both perceived usefulness and ease of use in our model. An additional direct relationship between playfulness and intention to use the program has been added and tested. Specifically, learners are assumed to gain playfulness through interactivity. Hypotheses regarding the relationships between playfulness and other factors were also proposed (see Figure 1 for illustration).

              H2: Interactive VR motion-control technology will increase learners’ perceived playfulness (as compared to passive observation)

              H3a: Perceived playfulness will have a positive effect on perceived ease of use (PP → PEU)

              H3b: Perceived playfulness will have a positive effect on perceived usefulness (PP → PU)

              H3c: Perceived playfulness will have a direct positive effect on intention to use the training (PP → IU)

              H3d: Perceived playfulness will have an indirect positive effect on intention to use the training through perceived ease of use (PP → PEU → IU)

              H3e: Perceived playfulness will have an indirect positive effect on intention to use the training through perceived usefulness (PP → PU → IU)

              H3f: Perceived playfulness will have an indirect positive effect on intention to use the training through perceived ease of use and perceived usefulness (PP → PEU → PU → IU)

              H4: Perceived ease of use will have a direct positive effect on intention to use the training (PEU → IU)

              H5: Perceived usefulness will have a direct positive effect on intention to use the training (PU → IU)

              2.3. Gender and TAM

              Gender is another factor that has recently received a considerable amount of interest in TAM literature. Some studies have suggested that environmental or contextual factors such as culture and gender difference should be further examined to test the generalizability and predictability of TAM (Dogruel, Joeckel, Bowman, 2015; Legris, Ingham, & Collerette, 2003; Marangunić & Granić, 2014; Sharp, 2007; Svendsen et al., 2013). The question of whether men and women differ on their perceptions and acceptances of the technology needs to be tested further.

              However, results of the gender effect on technology perception and acceptance are inconsistent. In some studies, little or no gender difference was found (Norris, Sullivan, Poirot., & Soloway, 2003; Teo, Fan, & Du, 2015; Whitley, 1997) whereas other studies suggested the existence of gender differences (Braak, 2004; Broos, 2005; Colley & Comber, 2003; Schumacher & Morahan-Martin, 2001). For example, surveying pre-service teachers about their attitudes toward using technology in their professional work, Teo et al. (2015) found no gender differences on how perceived usefulness and ease of use attribute to teachers’ intention to use technology. They argued that applicability of TAM is not restricted to the sampled population. Similarly, Whitley (1997) found little or no gender differences in computer-related attitudes and behavior among US and Canadian participants. However, other studies have found that men have higher self-efficacy, perceived computer-experience or confidence than women in using PC or communication technology (Braak, 2004; Broos, 2005; Ong & Lai, 2006). In addition, in exploring the relationship among acceptance determinants, Ong and Lai (2006) found that men’s acceptance rates for using e-learning are significantly influenced by their perception of the usefulness of the technology. Similarly, Padilla-Meléndez et al. (2013) also suggested a gender difference was evident in terms of perceived playfulness and technological acceptance of using Moodle (a computerized distance e-learning system). Therefore, it is clear that the effect of gender on technological acceptance needs to be explored further.

              Despite the fact that the influence of gender is not yet conclusive, on a theoretical basis, TAM suggests that gender is an important contextual factor. Technology acceptance may depend upon the gender of the user (characteristic of the users). Perceived usefulness has a stronger impact on men’s acceptance of technology whereas the perceived ease of use is a more important determinant for women (Terzis & Economides, 2011a). Thus, this study explored the gender differences in perceptions and acceptance of the VR-interactive motion-control spatial training programs. It is hypothesized that:

              H6: Males’ and females’ (H6a) ease of use, (H6b) perceived usefulness (H6c) intention to use the program, and (H6d) perceived playfulness will be different in the experimental condition

              H7: The relationships between the playfulness and perceived usefulness, perceived of ease of use, and intention to use will be different between genders in the experimental condition if a gender effect exists

              3. Methodology

              3.1. Research method and conditions

              To understand the influence of the motion-control function on the learner, we targeted student’s MR ability as an example for computer-assisted learning on spatial ability. We employed an experimental method and administered a quantitative questionnaire survey. The interactive motion-control training and observation-only MR training programs were developed and compared. The dependent variables included: (1) perceived playfulness, (2) ease of use, (3) usefulness, and (4) behavioral intention. First, students took the pretests to evaluate their initial MR ability and were then randomly assigned to different training programs. After completion of the training, students took a survey.

              The stimuli used were drawn from 3D geometric objects from the Vandenberg and Kuse MR test (Vandenberg & Kuse, 1978). The presentation mode was, however, based on the test method from Shepard and Metzler (1971), in which two 3D objects were simultaneously projected on the right and left sides of the screen. In both conditions, 3D VR technology allows students to experience a vivid stereoscopic vision through 3D glass and a projector. However, learners in the experimental group were provided with a magnetic motion remote control (similar to the Wii [Nintendo] game-console controller), which allowed learners to interact intuitively with the 3D object. Thus, an interactive motion-control function was provided to aid students’ judgment process. They were able to rotate one of the 3D objects on the screen. In the control group (observation-only), one 3D object automatically rotated and moved while the learner passively watched and determined whether the two items were identical. The following describes the training activities across the experimental condition and control groups.

              3.1.1. Experimental group

              Manual rotation training consisted of two learning activities. In the first learning activity, the users rotated and moved a controllable object (using the magnetic motion sensor controller) until it was completely superimposed onto a target object (both location and object orientation needed to match). Overall, there were 48 trials conducted for this superimposed activity. In the second learning activity, users determined whether the two objects had the same geometric shape with the help of a motion-control aid. Users were able to rotate the orientation of the controllable object while the location of the object remained fixed. In other words, the object remained stationary in one location while users rotated it. The aim was for users to rotate the object and verify whether the two items were identical in terms of shape (Figure 2a). The second learning activity also included 48 trials.

              How Motion-Control Influences a VR-Supported Technology for Mental Rotation Learning: From the Perspectives of Playfulness, Gender Difference and Technology Acceptance Model

              All authors
              Po-Han Lin & Shih-Ching Yeh
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2019.1571784
              Published online:
              12 February 2019

              Figure 2. Examples of the (a) motion-control 3D object training (left) and (b) observation-only training (right).

              Display full size

              Figure 2. Examples of the (a) motion-control 3D object training (left) and (b) observation-only training (right).

              3.1.2. Control group

              For the control group, a motion-control aid was not provided for either learning activity. The learning activities involved were identical to the experimental condition group (with 48 trials in total) except the trials were presented through animated videos. In the first learning activity, one of the two objects was automatically moved and rotated until it was superimposed onto the target. In the second learning activity, the comparison object automatically rotated while the participants evaluated the geometric shape of the objects (48 trials). Only passive observation was allowed (Figure 2b).

              3.2. Participants

              Initially, 76 college and graduate students (36 men and 41 women) were recruited. Students were recruited from an undergraduate elective computer-science class. Participation was voluntary (students received extra course credits if they participated). One participant was excluded due to the loss of his/her birthday data. Another participant was excluded because of an extreme MR test performance. The excluding criterion of z-score above 2.5, followed the specified value suggested by Vanselst and Jolicoeur (1994; see also Cousineau & Chartier, 2010 for review). Two other participants were excluded because of an un-pairing issue (see procedure below). Therefore, 72 participants (36 men) between the ages of 21–43 with an average age of 24.21 years old (mode = 22 years and SD = 5.03 years) were included. Thirty-six participants were in each group, half of which were men to counterbalance the gender effect. They majored in Chinese Literature, Finance, Business Administration, Information Management, Electrical Engineering, or Computer Science & Information Engineering.

              3.3. Procedure

              The informed consents were first obtained from the participants. Details were first explained to participants regarding the duration, procedure, and potential risks involved in the experiment. It was also explained that they could choose to withdraw from study at any time. For the VR group, participants were informed that some people might experience motion sickness or dizziness when using the stereoscopic glasses. Participants were instructed to tell the experimenter if they felt uncomfortable during the VR experience. During the study, none of the participants reported dizziness.

              The experiment was conducted over a 2-week period, covering two training activities. The total training time was 90 minutes. First, participants spent 10 minutes watching the instructional film and then engaged in the first activity for a 40-minute period. During the second week, the remaining 40 minutes were spent on the second activity. To ensure that the experimental and control groups possessed similar MR ability, students first took the Vandenberg and Kuse MR test (1978) to assess their initial MR ability. The students were then paired based on their MR scores and randomly assigned into two training groups. Students’ initial MR ability was checked using the t-test to compare students’ MR test scores between the two groups. No differences were found (experiment group = 13.22, SD = 4.11; control group = 13.58, SD = 4.47). Results of the t-test indicated that our pairing method was effective to equate MR ability. More importantly, it ensured that any differences of perception found between the training groups were not attributed to students’ initial MR ability.

              After two weeks of training, the participants were asked to complete a questionnaire. The survey aimed at understanding participants’ reaction regarding the following factors: playfulness, ease of use, usefulness and behavioral intentions. Questionnaires designed to evaluating playfulness (Martocchio & Webster, 1992) and technology acceptance (Davis, 1989) were adopted for this study. The full questionnaires are listed in the appendix section. The addition of the playfulness factor helped in the understanding of how factors are interrelated to one another in terms of their contributions to technology acceptance (potential use behavior). The internal consistency of the questionnaire was assessed by computing Cronbach’s alphas. Table 1 shows the values ranging from 0.88 (for playfulness) to 0.94 (for perceived usefulness). The validity and reliability of the scales were deemed adequate.

              How Motion-Control Influences a VR-Supported Technology for Mental Rotation Learning: From the Perspectives of Playfulness, Gender Difference and Technology Acceptance Model

              All authors

              4. Results

              4.1. Perceptions on two types of trainings

              SPSS (IBM Corp. Released 2013. IBM SPSS Statistics for Windows, Version 22.0. Armonk, NY: IBM Corp.) was used for all analyses. To test H1 and H2 that interactive motion-control training leads to higher perceived ease of use, usefulness, intention to use, and perceived playfulness than passive observation training, two-independent sample t-test comparisons were conducted. Consistent with both hypotheses, the availability of motion-control technology increased the above four variables. Table 2 illustrates the descriptive statistics and also the t-test summaries.

              How Motion-Control Influences a VR-Supported Technology for Mental Rotation Learning: From the Perspectives of Playfulness, Gender Difference and Technology Acceptance Model

              All authors
              Po-Han Lin & Shih-Ching Yeh
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2019.1571784
              Published online:
              12 February 2019

              Table 2. Descriptive statistics and t-tests results for perceived playfulness and TAM factors (ease of use, perceived usefulness, and intention to use) between experimental and control groups.

              CSVDisplay Table

              4.2. Mediation analysis on both conditions

              To test the proposed model as depicted in Figure 1, a regression-based path analysis was conducted to examine the interaction, direct and indirect effects in a mediation model (Hayes, 2012). Because of the small sample, we used nonparametric bootstrapping analyses (see Preacher & Hayes, 2004; Preacher, Rucker, & Hayes, 2007) to test the serial multiple-mediators model by using an existing computation tool (PROCESS; Model 6) provided in Hayes’ article (2012). The condition (training type) was entered as a covariance to control for the any effects of training type on intention. Direct effects are summarized in Figure 3.

              How Motion-Control Influences a VR-Supported Technology for Mental Rotation Learning: From the Perspectives of Playfulness, Gender Difference and Technology Acceptance Model

              All authors
              Po-Han Lin & Shih-Ching Yeh
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2019.1571784
              Published online:
              12 February 2019

              Figure 3. Mediation analysis results. The outer box frames the TAM proposed by Venkatesh and Davis (1996, p. 453).

              *p < .05. **p < .01.***p < .001.

              Display full size

              Figure 3. Mediation analysis results. The outer box frames the TAM proposed by Venkatesh and Davis (1996, p. 453).

              *p < .05. **p < .01.***p < .001.

              Ease of use and perceived usefulness were hypothesized to be the mediators in between perceived playfulness and intention to use the training program. The results based on 10000 bootstrapped samples indicated that the total effect of playfulness on intention (to use the training) was significant r = 0.235, p = .000. The direct effect of H3c = 0.134, p = .001 as well as the three indirect effects were also found to be significant as indicated by the fact that their bootstrap confidence intervals did not contain zero (Preacher & Hayes, 2004; Preacher et al., 2007).

              The first indirect effect (H3d) carried the effect of playfulness to ease of use and then onto the intention of use (indirect: PP → PEU → IU). This indirect effect is the combination effects of H3a = 0.409 and H4 = 0.107, or 0.0437, with a 95% bootstrap confidence interval of 0.0077 to 0.0983. The results indicated that those who perceived the training as more playful felt the training was easier and their willingness to use the training program increased. This indirect effect is independent of perceived usefulness. The second indirect effect (indirect: PP → PEU → PU → IU; H3f) is a product of H3a = 0.409, PEU → PU = 0.509, and H5 = 0.120, or 0.0249, with a 95% bootstrap confidence interval of 0.0107 to 0.0663. All three factors are positively associated with each other, and have contributed to increasing the intention of using the program. The third indirect carried the effect of playfulness to perceived usefulness and then onto the intention of use (indirect: PP → PU → IU; H3e). This is the product of H3b = 0.268 and H5 = 0.120, or 0.0322, with a confidence interval of 0.0082 to 0.0612. Again, the results showed that a high level of perceived playfulness is associated with a high level of perceived usefulness. A high level of playfulness may then lead to a high level of willingness to use the training program. The total effect of all the factors combined in explaining the variance of intention was 0.6199 or 61.99% (p = .000).

              Thus, mediation results were consistent with our hypotheses (H3, H4, and H5) that the interactive motion-control function increased the perception of playfulness of the training. More importantly, playfulness had both direct and indirect influences on intention of use through all three of the pathways depicted in the model (Figure 3).

              4.3. Difference regarding gender

              The results were partially consistent with hypothesis 6 that males and females in the experimental condition differed on two of the motivators (Table 3). For example, women regarded the interactive VR motion-control training as more playful than men (H6d). In addition, women also tended to regard the motion-control training as easier to use for MR training (H6a; marginal statistical significant, p = .056). However, men and women did not differ on perceived usefulness (H6b) and their intention for using the training program (H6d).

              How Motion-Control Influences a VR-Supported Technology for Mental Rotation Learning: From the Perspectives of Playfulness, Gender Difference and Technology Acceptance Model

              All authors
              Po-Han Lin & Shih-Ching Yeh
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2019.1571784
              Published online:
              12 February 2019

              Table 3. Descriptive statistics and t-tests results for perceived playfulness and TAM factors (ease of use, perceived usefulness, and intention to use) between genders in the experimental condition.

              CSVDisplay Table

              To test the gender effect, the same mediation analyses were conducted on male and female participants. For female participants, the total effect of all the factors combined in explaining the variance of intention was 0.535 or 53.5% (p = .0079). For male participants, the total effect of all the factors combined in explaining the variance of intention was 0.695 or 69.5% (p = .0015). The results indicated that for both genders, the proposed TAM models explained more than half of the variances found in participant’s intention to use the program. However, detailed mediation results showed that the underlying motivators for men and women to use the training program differed and as a result different patterns were found between genders (Figure 4). These results are consistent with our hypothesis 7 that the relationships between playfulness and perceived usefulness, perceived of ease of use, and intention to use would be different between genders if a gender effect exists. Details of how men and women differed are elaborated in the discussion section.

              How Motion-Control Influences a VR-Supported Technology for Mental Rotation Learning: From the Perspectives of Playfulness, Gender Difference and Technology Acceptance Model

              All authors
              Po-Han Lin & Shih-Ching Yeh
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2019.1571784
              Published online:
              12 February 2019

              Figure 4. Mediation analysis results between gender in the experimental condition.

              *p < .05. **p < .01. †p = .069. Red line represented result for women and blue dotted line is for men.

              Display full size

              Figure 4. Mediation analysis results between gender in the experimental condition.

              *p < .05. **p < .01. †p = .069. Red line represented result for women and blue dotted line is for men.

              5. Discussion

              The goal of this study is to evaluate students’ perception of using the interactive VR motion-control technology for MR learning purposes. The learning methods of active involvement and passive observation were compared from the TAM perspective. Furthermore, gender differences were also explored in regard to men and women’s acceptance of the VR motion-control technology. Three interesting findings emerged and are discussed in more detail below.

              First, higher scores for the three motivators (perceived ease of use, usefulness, and playfulness) and intention to use the interactive motion-control program (Table 2) were found in the experiment group than in the control group. This is consistent with the current educational concept of learning by doing. For example, Winebrenner (2003) proposed that “manipulation of objects often helps these students understand concepts more clearly when they are transferred to more abstract applications within content areas” (p. 135). Johnson (2008) believed that knowledge is more than pure thinking. It is rather an act of thinking based on fundamental feelings and physical movement. It is through the interaction of the body and the environment, that the learner’s experience of learning and cognitive processes is increased (Johnson, 2008). Students’ comments recorded after their training program also complied with these concepts. For instance, students who engaged in a learning process without a motion-control system expressed responses such as, “This object has appeared many times,” “All I can do is look at the screen,” and “Can I do something else?” On the other hand, the primary responses from the students using the motion-control system included: “That’s how it works” and “I should rotate it in this direction or way.” These comments suggested that the students continually implemented corrective actions according to their errors. They noticed that error correction could be conducted directly without waiting until the entire learning session was complete. In sum, while both conditions employed VR technology, only the feeling of being in control provided by the motion-control technology elicited a higher sense of playfulness and is better accepted by the users.

              Second, regardless of gender, the participants operated according to the TAM, and the perceived playfulness factor directly influenced the three primary factors of the TAM. Perceived playfulness had direct and indirect effect on users’ intention to use the program. Results were partially consistent with previous studies that considered playfulness as an antecedent factor to perceived ease of use and perceived usefulness (e.g., Hong et al., 2011; Padilla-Meléndez et al., 2013; Venkatesh, 2000; Venkatesh & Bala, 2008; Yi & Hwang, 2003). However, not all the studies showed that playfulness is directly related to intention of use. In the context of computer-assisted spatial training, our results suggest that playfulness has a direct impact on intention of use.

              Third, differences between perception of males and females were still found despite the fact that VR and motion-control technologies are no longer thought of as an innovation or uncommon. Women perceived the motion-control function as more fun and easier to use (Table 3). For both men and women, perceived ease of use is the major contributor to use intention and perceived usefulness was not found to be related to use intention. Men and women also differed on how each motivator influenced their use intention. For men, perceived playfulness is related to perceived of ease of use and the ease of use is directly related to use intention. Playfulness is not directly related to use intention. For women, perceived playfulness is more related to perceived usefulness. More importantly, it was only found in women that playfulness is directly related to use intention.

              The effect of gender might result from individual’s self-efficacy or experiences of using the technology (Terzis & Economides, 2011a; Venkatesh, 2000; Venkatesh & Bala, 2008). Women still perceived the VR and motion-control technologies as being more fun and novel. Future computer-assistant learning may target using these technologies on women to increase the feeling of ease of use and to reduce cognitive load or anxiety. In contrast, men focused more on the functionality of the technology. Designers who wish to use VR and motion-control technologies could increase the task difficulty or add other attractive functions to increase male students’ perceived playfulness of the system. For male users, there is a focus on understanding the purpose of the training and how the technology can assist them to achieve that goal.

              6. Conclusion

              This study focused on how motion-control (interactivity) function influences learners’ acceptance of a VR-supported technology for MR learning. Technology acceptance and the feeling of playfulness were compared between an active VR motion-control training condition and passive observation learning condition. Our results suggested that VR along with a motion-control (interactivity) function is still considered compelling to digital native college students (Junco & Mastrodicasa, 2007). The acceptance (12.14) and playfulness (38.06) scores reported by the students in the experimental condition were higher than the acceptance (9.31) and playfulness (31.31) scores reported in the control group. In addition, computer-assisted learning designers should be aware of the subtle gender difference in accepting the motion-control technology for learning purpose. Our results indicated that women perceived the VR interactive learning system as being more playful (41.44) and easier to use (38.28) than men (34.67 and 34.89 on perceived playfulness and ease of use, respectively). We suggest that the basic function of VR and interactivity might not be enough to elicit interest or motivation among male students. This study contributes to the current trend of investigating user’s acceptance and motivation/perceptions when using a new educational technology in supporting spatial learning (Carbonell-Carrera et al., 2018; Carbonell-Carrera & Saorín, 2017). It also contributes in providing empirical support that TAM factors and playfulness are related to use of a technology in a spatial learning domain.

              Dimension#Questionnaires
              Playfulness1I felt the time went by quickly when I was immersed in the learning system
              2I often forget what is the main purpose of the learning system while I performed the tasks
              3I enjoy solving the tasks in the learning system
              4I think the operation of this learning system is fun to use
              5I find this learning system playful
              6I think this learning system enhances my learning motivation
              7I think this learning system inspires my learning creativity
              Dimensions#Questionnaires
              Usefulness1Using this learning system enables me to accomplish MR tasks more quickly
              2Using this learning system improves my MR performance
              3Using this learning system allows me to accomplish more work than would otherwise be possible
              4Using this learning system enhances my effectiveness of finishing the MT tasks
              5Using this learning system makes it easier to do the MT tasks
              6Overall, I find this learning system useful
              Ease of Use1Learning to operate the learning system is easy for me
              2I find it easy to get the learning system to do what I want it to do
              3It is easy for me to remember how to perform tasks using the learning system
              4I find the use of the learning system interactive and flexible
              5My interaction with the learning system is clear and understandable
              6Overall, I find this learning system easy to use
              Intention to Use1If you have a chance to use this learning system to train your spatial ability, are you willing to use it?
              2If your friends need to train their mental rotation ability in the future, will you recommend them to use this learning system?

International Journal of Human-Computer Studies, 59(4), 431–449. doi:10.1016/S1071-5819(03)00114-9 [Crossref], [Web of Science ®], [Google Scholar]
              • Zainab, B., Bhatti, M. A., & Alshagawi, M. (2017). Factors affecting e-training adoption: An examination of perceived cost, computer self-efficacy and the technology acceptance model. Behaviour & Information Technology, 36(12), 1261–1273. doi:10.1080/0144929X.2017.1380703 [Taylor & Francis Online], [Web of Science ®], [Google Scholar]

              Additional information

              Author information

              Po-Han Lin

              Po-Han Lin is an Assistant Professor at the National Taipei University of Education. He received his Ph.D. in Education from National Central University, Taiwan, in 2015 and M.A. and B.S. in Cognitive Psychology from the University of Iowa (USA). His research focuses on cognitive load theory, computer-assisted learning, and testing.

              Shih-Ching Yeh

              Shih-Ching Yeh received his Ph.D. degrees in Computer Science at the University of Southern California in 2008. Currently, he is a research professor in the School of Information Science and Technology at Fudan University. His research interests emphasize employing virtual reality in neuromotor rehabilitation, cognitive training, and digital learning.
